summary: Email chain between FBI forensic examiners and a U.S. Attorney's Office prosecutor regarding the status of evidence processing in the Epstein case, focusing on the delivery and completeness of digital evidence files, including thumb drives and servers requiring physical recovery.

persons.name: M. I.
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the processing and delivery of digital evidence in the Epstein case, responding to questions about evidence status and file completeness.

persons.name: (USANYS)
persons.context: Prosecutor from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York inquiring about the status and completeness of Epstein evidence files, including specific device numbers and zero-byte file issues.

connections.description: FBI forensic examiner and prosecutor communicating about evidence processing and delivery in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Evidence status update email
events.description: Email exchange regarding the status of Epstein digital evidence processing, confirming completion of most files and noting remaining items requiring physical recovery.

events.title: Evidence spreadsheet update
events.description: Forensic examiner provides updated spreadsheet of Epstein evidence with color coding and notes on pending items.

keyFacts: The document reveals ongoing evidence processing in the Epstein case as of August 2020, with FBI forensic examiners coordinating with prosecutors.
Specific evidence items mentioned include thumb drives (NYC027913) and servers with physically failed drives requiring specialized recovery at FBI HQ.
The email chain discusses approximately 71,000 zero-byte (empty) files found in the initial seven devices, which the forensic examiner states is not unusual for recovery software.
Multiple evidence items are referenced by NYC numbers (e.g., NYC024328, NYC024366, NYC024392) indicating systematic tracking of seized devices.
The correspondence is subject to a protective order restricting disclosure of certain paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17).
